Graphical abstract The compositions of lithium-ion batteries and lithium-sulfur batteries, as well as the advance designs of LDH based on preparation methods and mechanism analysis for the electrochemical components of the two batteries. Lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery and lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery have attracted significant attention as promising components for large-scale energy storage because of high theoretical capacity of Li, excellent energy density or environmental friendness for two kinds of batteries. However, there still exist some respective obstacles for commercial applications, such as limited theoretical capacity, high cost and low conductivity of Li-ion cells or shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides of Li-S cells. As typical two-dimensional materials, layered double hydroxides (LDHs) exhibit excellent potential in the field of energy storage due to facile tunability of composition, structure and morphology as well as convenient composite and strong catalytic properties. Consequently, various LDHs toward novel separators or interlayers, cathodes, anodes, and interesting catalytic templates are researched to resolve these challenges. In this review, the recent progress for LDHs applied in Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries including the synthesis methods, designs and applications is presented and reviewed. Meanwhile, the existing challenges and future perspectives associated with material designs and practical applications of LDHs for these two classes of cells are discussed. WeWe hope that the review can attract more attention and inspire more profound researches toward the LDH-based electrochemical materials for energy storage. Keywords Layered double hydroxide Synthesis methods Structural designs Lithium-ion battery Lithium-sulfur battery Electrochemical performances 1 Introduction With the rapid enhancements of science and technology and the fast-growing daily demands, the shortage of fossil energy is increasingly aggravated. Therefore, solar energy and wind energy are gradually emerging. However, these energy systems have certain limitations due to their intermittent and uncontrollable characteristics. Due to the energy crisis, higher requirements have been put forward to develop secondary batteries with exceptional systems for energy storage and transmission. Especially the Lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery was spread to commercial applications. With the minimum density of 0.53 g cm−3, chemical equivalent of 0.26 g A−1h−1 and high theoretical specific capacity of 3861 mAh g−1, metal lithium exhibits low reduction potential, superior energy density and high voltage in assembled cells. Li-ion battery traditionally contains carbon anode, lithium-salt electrolyte, and cathode such as the most widespread LiCoO2, LiMn2O4 and LiFePO4. Lithium ions are intercalated and deintercalated between anode and cathode, along with the insertion and de-insertion of equivalent electrons which complete the battery charge and discharge processes as Fig. 1 (a) [1]. However, the conundrums of Li-ion cells lie in the high cost of cathode materials and the electrochemical performances approaching the theoretical limits, which hinder its further development. Nowadays, sulfur, the redundant by-product in the petroleum industry, has attracted more attention due to rich raw materials, low cost and suitable for conversion of multielectron. The Li-S battery with a higher theoretical energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1 and a volumetric energy density of 2800 Wh L−1, which is regarded as one of the most promising rechargeable batteries. It is usually composed of sulfur cathode, separator, electrolyte and lithium anode. The operation principle of Li-S battery is presented in Fig. 1(b) [2], in which lithium ions diffuse from the anode to the cathode and react with S8 during the discharge process. At the same time, constant moving electrons transfer electric energy through peripheral circuits. Electric energy is converted to chemical energy when charged. Nonetheless, there are significant obstacles toward Li-S batteries, mainly reflecting in the rapid attenuation of capacity. These are attributed to the low conductivity of elemental sulfur and discharge products Li2S y (1 ≤ y < 3), the loss of active substances and waste of energy caused by the dissolution of lithium polysulfides (their “shuttle effect”), serious damage of lithium dendrites, inhomogeneous solid electrolyte interface (SEI), huge volume changes and low elemental sulfur loading. As typical two-dimensional (2D) and inorganic layered materials, layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are a kind of anionic clays composed of metal cations and interlamellar guest anions, which are also known as hydrotalcite-like materials. The first synthesis of LDH was an alkaline CaAl double compound developed by Feitknecht in Germany in 1942. Until the 1960s, Allmann and Taylor et al. reported and analyzed the detailed structure as hydrotalcite with layered features using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) [3,4]. The historical timeline of the development of LDH materials and applications in the field of energy storage is shown in Fig. 1(c). The adjustable combination of metal ions, readily exchangeable anions and the delaminated structure endow LDHs numerous applications in some aspects such as catalysis, adsorption, biology, ion exchange host, additive and nanocomposite template. The macroscopic and microscopic structure advantages of 2D nanosheets are extremely valuable in the fields of electrons, photons and magnetism. Coupled with their remarkable charge properties, easy conversion into electroactive materials, facile chemical modification and exfoliation into monolayer nanosheets, the practices have made Li-based batteries acquire staged progress. LDHs exhibit a strong dependence on conductivity about hydration state, on both the nature of intercalated anion and hydroxylated framework, which means that they can provide high ionic conductivity, content of transition metal oxide and thermal stability for battery [5]. As for Li-based batteries, the compounds and the heteroatom-doped carbon materials derived by LDHs create chemical bonding force through combining with “Li bonds”. Based on the intriguing features mentioned above, the deficiencies in capacity attenuation and safety are alleviated via designing the well-controlled nanostructure including the macroscopic morphology of nanomaterials, hierarchical architectures and self-assembled three-dimensional (3D) system, as well as hybrid nanocomposites. In 1988, Steven et al. [6] systematically described the preparation, characterization and general application of LDHs containing organic guests and pointed out the range of organic matters which can be incorporated into LDHs. The organic-inorganic supramolecular structure opened up more profound directions for development of LDHs. Wang et al. [7] summarized the researches toward LDH nanosheets. Zhao and his co-workers [8] recapitulated the hierarchical nanocomposites derived from nanocarbon and LDHs through multiple structures and strategies in the same year. Shao et al. [9] integrated the study of LDHs in terms of designs, synthesis and uses for energy storage and conversion as supercapacitors and electrochemical catalysis. With the continuous development of LDHs, they have been widely used in energy systems. The experiment researches and patents about LDHs applied in Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries all showed a momentum of rapid growth and achieve significant progress year by year. However, up to now, the review literature about LDHs for Li-ion cells and Li-S cells is still totally blank. In this review, we comprehensively summarize recent advances in synthesis methods, designs, mechanisms and applications of LDHs toward Li-ion cells and Li-S cells. Importantly, we highlight unique structural designs including hollow polyhedron, core-shell, nanowall array, layer by layer (LBL), flower pattern, sandwich-type and rich composite strategies in two kinds of batteries as shown in Fig. 2 . It is worth noting that the theoretical basis and groundbreaking ideas for synthetic routes and means to improve performances of batteries are stimulated based on these idiographic structure designs. Meanwhile, the existing challenges and future perspectives of LDHs are discussed. It is anticipated that the review will attract more attention toward the LDH-based materials and encourage more advanced researches in other electrochemical components and wider range of applications. 2 Synthesis, structural designs and mechanisms LDHs are referred to as a kind of anionic clays, which can be represented by the general formula [M2+ 1− x M3+ x (OH)2 ]A n − x / n ∙mH2O. The M2+ and M3+ are divalent and trivalent cations. The x points to a molar ratio of M3+/(M2++M3+) generally ranging from 0.2 to 0.33. A means the exchangeable inorganic or organic anions with valence n in the interlayer galleries. There are commonly used cations like Mg2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+ or Zn2+ and trivalent cations such as Al3+, Fe3+, Cr3+ and Mn3+. The macroscopic appearance of general LDH represents hexagonal flakes. The lateral size of the exfoliated single LDH is tens of nanometers to several micrometers and the thickness is tens of nanometers. In the microstructure, the hydroxide ions of LDHs are at the position of the accumulation of hexagonal atoms, while two cations occupy alternating layers of octahedral sites. The empty layer at the octahedral site constitutes an interlayer channel, and charge compensating anions are inserted into the interlayer galleries together with water molecules [10]. The LDHs are consisted of a stack of positively charged mixed metal hydroxide layers due to the substitution of divalent metal cations with that of trivalent. Thus the presence of interlayer anions balances overall charge neutrality. There are extremely wide ranges of additional objects that can be incorporated into LDHs, including inorganic macromolecules and organic macromolecules, such as sulfonates, phosphonates, aliphatic and aromatic carboxylates. However, LDH usually does not directly participate in electrochemical reactions as active substances in the practical applications of Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries. The most common form is calcination of LDH into layered double dioxide (LDO) with single-crystalline structure which is mainly composed of mixed metal oxides or spinels. It is known that the topological evolution of LDHs underwent in the process of calcination. Several steps occur successively with the rise of calcination temperature: the two dehydrations occurred by removing crystal water in the interlayer and decomposing of hydroxide ions in the positively charged layer, respectively. Subsequently, decarbonization reactions caused by decomposition of CO3 2− and the formation of the spinel phase arose. Then the hydrotalc structure was completely destroyed, but the platelet morphology and hierarchical structure of LDHs can be preserved [11]. Moreover, the oxygen-capped surface of the LDO platelet catalyzed the decomposition of the carbon source, resulting in uniform deposition of carbon on the exposed surface. Besides, there are transition metal compounds derived from LDHs, such as sulfides and phosphates, as electrochemically active materials. Based on the above characteristics of LDHs, especially the properties of anion exchange and embedding, it is a valuable research direction to integrate the distinguishing advantages through solely carbonized LDHs or LDH/nanocarbon composite materials. The nanocarbon composites provide advanced electrical conductivity and mechanical strength creating a network of stress transfer. Furthermore, those derivatives easily form hierarchical porous structures to fully expose the active sites and construct electronic paths. These properties bring LDHs and derivatives a bright prospect in electrochemical applications for Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries. 2.1 Preparation of LDHs At present, the main synthetic methods of LDHs include ion exchange, co-precipitation and hydrothermal synthesis. On this basis, a variety of electrochemical materials were obtained through post-treatment and structural designs. 2.1.1 Ion exchange Newman et al. [6] considered that LDH containing nitrate anions is the most suitable precursor for anion exchange owing to relatively low selectivity in the exchangeability of anions. The precursor LDHs are dispersed in aqueous solution containing an excess of new anion with higher exchangeability, such as inorganic anions OH−, SO4 2− and CO3 2− as well as organic anions benzoate [12], dodecyl sulfate [13] and β-cyclodextrin derivative [6]. Miyata and Kumura firstly put forward the exchange of interlamellar anions by organic ions (dicarboxylic acid anions) with acetate in 1973 [14]. Various LDHs were prepared with different cations and organic anions using the anion exchange strategy in the 1990s [15]. It introduced the molecular arrangement and proved the high intra-crystalline reactivity. The anion exchange mechanism can be applied to insert functional anions between the interlayer of LDHs. Benzoate and two derivatives were inserted in the layers of ZnAl LDHs by Mishra et al. as shown in Fig. 3 (a) [12]. The structural formula, size and shape of the molecule of the guest anion all affected the interlayer distance which was related to the angle of anion insertion, in turn affected the performances of the battery. In the aspect of preparing ultra-fine NiFe LDH nanosheets embedded with various anions, Jiang et al. [13] introduced a method to prepare LDH/carbon composites by single-step precipitation combining with anion exchange. The strategy was more convenient than the two-step assembly strategy containing exfoliation of LDHs and hetero-assembly of graphene. 2.1.2 Co-precipitation In 1942, W. Feitknecht et al. devised an idea to precipitate a mixture of chloride of Mg/Al and Ca/Al with excess sodium hydroxide to form double compound. The LDHs prepared by the co-deposition have been extensively used in the cells. In a nutshell, the soluble metal ion salt solution reacted with alkali solution to precipitate and form the corresponding LDH grains. Usually, the nitrate, sulfate or chloride containing appropriate metal ions are introduced due to their high affinity and low selectivity. The alkali solution can be potassium hydroxide, ammonium hydroxide, sodium carbonate, potassium carbonate, urea and so on. The key factor is to control the pH of the solution, which greatly affects the purity, crystallinity and whether they are precipitated in the expected M2+/M3+ ratio. The methods of adjustment include variable-pH precipitation and constant-pH precipitation. The differences in effect are that the former LDHs had high surface area and fine grained crystals, and the latter had well-formed morphology but larger size [16]. Another outstanding virtue of the co-precipitation is that LDHs can be easily compounded with various matrices as polymer and nanocarbon accompanied by synthetic procedure. The latter is commonly used for electrode materials in Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries, as well as widespread means to enhance conductivity. As for LDHs/polymer composites, for example, NiFe LDH/MXene composite electrodes were developed combining the high conductivity, flexibility and abundant functional groups of MXene [17]. The method of urea hydrolysis was independent with the method of co-precipitation in some literature: When the temperature exceeded 90 °C, the hydrolysis of urea led to the increase of pH. Naseem et al. [18] synthesized and compared a series of ternary LDHs by urea hydrolysis (Fig. 3(b)), by which the as-prepared nanosheets were thinner and more uniform size than traditional co-precipitation. A method similar to but superior to ordinary co-precipitation is the electro-deposition method. Dennis et al. firstly synthesized Ni-based hydroxides by metallic nitrate solution via electrochemical co-precipitation in 1989 [19]. By reducing anions to produce OH−, the local pH on the applied electrode was increased to control the precipitation of corresponding LDHs. In brief, the reasons why the co-precipitation has been widely used in cells are that it could be carried out at normal temperature and pressure, and it could retain the initial ratio of metal ions. What′s more, the type of anions in applied interlayer could be adjusted directly through changing the salt solution. However, it requires extra aging or colloidal dissolution after the initial co-precipitation to obtain LDHs with rich crystallization and layered morphology. And the difference in concentration resulted from uneven micro-mixing gives rise to slightly larger size and poor uniformity of LDHs. 2.1.3 Hydrothermal method The hydrothermal synthesis refers to that the dissolved products further reach the supersaturated state to grow and crystallize under the condition of high temperature (100–1000 °C) and putting pressure (1 MPa–1 GPa) in an airtight vessel. For instance, the nitrate consisting of Co2+, Fe3+, Al3+ and mixed alkaline solution in stainless steel autoclave preformed hydrothermal treatment and eventually transformed into the ternary LDH powders [20]. Moreover, the facile hydrothermal method is also frequently used to achieve fancy structure loaded on various substrates. The NiCo LDH nanowall arrays, resorted to carbon cloth coated with ZnO nanorods, were manufactured under similar sealed and high-temperature conditions [21]. The method compensated the uneven particle size resulted from that particles were generated one by one in the co-precipitation. The two steps, nucleation and crystallization under high pressure, were carried out separately in hydrothermal synthesis. And the selections of hydrothermal conditions and modes of ions determine whether the LDHs with the crystal structure and physicochemical characteristics can be formed. These two points are valuable for Li-ion cells and Li-S cells. By adjusting the reaction temperature and time to control the effect of crystallization, the LDHs with effectual crystallization, less agglomeration, high purity, and narrow particle size distribution were obtained. It is beneficial to ameliorate electrochemical activity and cycling lifespan. But the inherent downsides are strict conditions and relatively low utilization rate of reactants. Therefore, the method in this aspect needs to be further improved. 2.1.4 Other synthesis strategies In addition to the above three common methods, reverse micelle/microemulsion, rehydration of calcination and instant synthesis also were applied to synthesize LDHs. Microemulsion is a thermodynamically stable and isotropic system which is formed by two insoluble liquids. Under the action of surfactant, the instantaneous interfacial tension leads to the spontaneous expansion of the system interface, which achieves a balanced interaction between aggregation and expansion. The reactants are dispersed in the microemulsion. And the microemulsion can be acted as microreactor to provide limited space and nutrients for the formation of single-layered LDH platelets as Fig. 3(c). Hu et al. [22] firstly proposed a controlled synthesis of LDHs with a diameter of 40–50 nm and a thickness of 10 nm by water-in-oil reverse microemulsion of dodecyl sulfate. The way was proven to be able to synthesize LDHs with a variety of cations, but it was not applied on a large scale in the two outlined cells. The synthesized LDHs exhibited maneuverable size which much smaller than co-precipitation, controllable and superior dispersion [23] and high interlayer density. It is of great significance to explore electrode materials. Rehydration/hydration reconstruction of calcined LDH precursor is derived from the memory effect of hydrotalcite. According to the report of Miyata [24], the metal oxide derived from calcined hydrotalcite can be hydrated to reconstruct the structure of LDH in anion solution. It utilized adsorption and regeneration of roasted hydrotalcite and eliminated the competition of inorganic anions. Wang et al. [25] prepared first MgAl LDHs via co-precipitation, then they calcined them into LDOs which adsorbed organic anionic dyes in a CO2 free atmosphere. The LDOs were eventually converted to new LDHs by hydration reconstruction. As the anode of Li-ion cells, the final 2D hierarchical carbons were composed of graphene-like carbon nanosheets uniformly covered on hexagonal carbon nanoplates. But the defect of the method lied in inhomogeneous crystalline phase owing to the high affinity of oxides for carbonate anions. The preparation of LDHs described above by Wang's team [26] also involved another synthesis strategy: instant synthesis. It referred to make the best of the cation or anion presented in the wastewater. Meanwhile, magnesium chloride, aluminum chloride and alkali were added to remove the pollutants. In terms of operation, eliminating the complicated separation of solid–liquid and drying operation, it integrated two separate industrial processes of LDHs synthesis and wastewater treatment. The bright spot lies in simultaneously realizing of synthesizing products and controlling waste via waste. 2.2 Structural designs of LDHs for electrochemical materials Depending on the application fields, there are diverse strategies for structural designs of LDHs. On the basis of the above synthesis methods, aiming at the requirements and existing defects of Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries, the researchers developed various LDH-based electrochemical materials with particular structures and composite forms. Relying on different techniques and frameworks, LBL, hollow, core–shell, nanowall arrays, and other diverse architectures, as well as granular structure, nanocomposite structure were formed, which gave the batteries superb electrochemical performances. 2.2.1 Layer by layer structure LDHs have been demonstrated to able to achieve LBL self-assembly based on applying different types of materials [26,27]. To highlight the functionality, the LDH crystallites are exfoliated into the positively charged monolayer. They are alternately assembled with negatively charged materials including small molecules, metal complexes, macromolecules or polymers and anionic nanoparticles like Au and CdS. The spontaneous and regular structural reorganization can be used to construct ultra-thin multi-layer hybrid films with restricted channels, such as organic–inorganic hybrid composites [28] and LDH/carbon composites. Chen et al. [29] cyclically immersed LDH nanosheets, polyvinyl alcohol, graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets and polyvinyl alcohol into solution. The multi-layer nanocomposites of monolayer dispersed LDHs and graphene based on hydrogen bonding were obtained. It is worth mentioning the co-deposition method in the form of LBL. Yuan et al. [30] reported a method to achieve LBL deposited LDHs/nanofibers/polypyrrole ternary composites. The obtained composites are porous powders with flexible 3D networks. The specific surface area and composition of ternary composites can be well tailored by the simple synthesis method. 2.2.2 Polyhedron and core–shell structure Metal organic framework (MOF) is a compound with the porous and well-arranged crystal structure, which is composed of metal ions and organic ligands. Due to poor conductivity, it is often applied only as a sacrificial template. The LDHs grown on MOFs have large specific surface area, high porosity and hollow structures. The NiCo LDO nanosheets with honeycomb structure on the MOF/nickel foam by electro-deposition were established [31]. However, the poor conductivity of MOF restricts the rate capacity and cycling performance. Therefore, LDHs derived from MOF are usually combined with nanocarbon materials. Niu et al. [32] reported N-doped LDH nanosheet arrays derived from MOFs on carbon nanotube (CNT) films. And Chu et al. [33] resorted to the hollow structure of MOFs to design derivatives NiFe2O4 in combination with ultra-thin flower-like NiCo-LDH/rGO (Fig. 3(d)). The most universal sacrificial template, the Zeolitic imidazole framework (ZIF), presents a polyhedral framework that could be used as the source of metal and auxiliary gas. Generally, combining with the chemical vapor deposition (CVD), LDHs are enriched in nitrogen element by the pyrolysis of ZIF which helps to absorb lithium polysulfides. Applying this method, Zhang et al. [34] prepared hollow polyhedral NiCoZn LDHs through ZIF-67 tightly and uniformly embedded on carbon nanofibers (CNFs). The structure offered a favorable mechanical robustness and 3D long-range conductivity for sulfur electrochemical reactions. However, the synthetic method for LDH hollow microsphere template is complicated, expensive and difficult to large-scale production. So scientists have developed other sacrificial templates. Tao et al. [35] constructed hydrangea-shaped NiCo LDH hollow microspheres applying SiO2 nanospheres as templates for Li-ion batteries. It is worth promoting that the formation rate of the NiCo LDH nanosheets was comparable to the dissolution rate of the SiO2 which made sure the formation of the cavity structure and hydrangea appearance. Besides, the adsorptive base sources and the steps of removal of templates can be omitted. 2.2.3 Nanowall arrays structure The LDH nanowall arrays on the substrate present directional and rigid structures. It means that the active materials are grown directly on the conductive carriers, which shortens the ion diffusion path and enhances the adhesion between the carriers and active guests. To satisfy the pursuit of thin materials for Li-ion batteries, Li et al. [36] investigated the ultra-thin mesoporous Co3O4 nanowall arrays with approximately 2 nm thickness by calcining the LDH arrays. Jiang et al. [37] obtained vertically arranged LDH nanowall arrays based on heterogeneous nucleation growth mechanism. The in-situ growth pattern improved the consolidation of surface resulted from polymer adhesives, ensuring the transfer of electron and penetration of electrolyte. The so-called in situ growth method is to put the conductive substrate (carbon matrix and nickel foam, etc.) into the metal salt solution, in which the metal ions deposit to form LDHs on the surface of the substrate. The mode also enables to coat colloidal suspension containing LDH seeds on the substrate to form a more uniform LDH film with higher crystallinity [6]. In particular, the participation of ethanol regulates the growth behavior of LDH nanoarrays, which endows the superior property than H2O molecules or CO3 2− ions to promote the formation of the hierarchical structure [38]. 2.2.4 Granular structure At present, the obstacles of synthesized LDHs in the field of batteries are large size and poor uniformity. The uneven mixing of reactants in the ordinary co-precipitation method leads to different times of nucleation and wider size distribution. The researchers developed LDHs with granular structure by decreasing the ratio of length/diameter (diameter/thickness) to meet various needs. Instead of the stirred tank reactor (STR), Chen et al. [39] developed rotating packed bed (RPB) reactor utilizing the high-gravity-assisted co-precipitation approach to achieve monodispersed MgAl LDH nanoparticles with the size of 31 nm. Under the action of gravity, the mixture rapidly broke up into tiny droplets, which in turn promptly nucleate. Meanwhile, RPB acted as a superb site for micromixing and mass transfer of reactants and shortened growth period. Pang et al. [40] carried out the co-precipitation in T-type microchannel reactor, in which the re-dispersed nanocrystals gradually self-assembled and grew longitudinally into 3D LDHs. Layrac et al. [41] obtained MgAl LDH nanoparticles with controllable size and low aggregation in the form of aqueous colloids. The LDH catalysts may give rise to higher activity and accessibility of sites. Up to now, the applications of LDH nanoparticles for electrode have not been extensively concerned. The more innovative schemes will be introduced into Li-ion cells and Li-S cells. They upgrade LDHs with small size, well-dispersion, 3D architecture to the templates or body materials of electrodes with high activity, large specific surface area, low aggregation and novel structures. 2.2.5 Composite structure The derivatives of LDHs possess high specific capacity, but they are confronted with huge volume change and extremely low electrical conductivity. For that, composites with 3D conductive networks and open architecture can protect the fragile structures. In Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries, the designs of LDH-based composite structures principally involve polymer/LDH composites and nanocarbon/LDH composites, which have attracted extensive attention. Zhang et al. [42] adopted the surface-confined strategy to construct ultra-thin, wrinkled, bent and larger interlayer spaced NiCo LDHs on Ti3C2 MXene as anode for Li-ion battery. The chemical interactions between the compound components can improve the ability of diffusion and reduced internal resistance. The decisive compound component, Ti3C2 MXene, in which the −F and −OH terminated groups were removed from the surface in the reaction process. The design alleviated structural degradation and achieved high electrical conductivity, low diffusion barrier and excellent discharge capacity. As for nanocarbon/LDH composites, the main mechanism of electrostatic assembly is that carbon materials bear negative charges and LDHs have positively charged surface. The strong electrostatic force makes the two tightly anchored, ensuring efficient electronic transmission in the batteries. It also endows the negatively charged surface a strong ability to adsorb metal cations in solution. According to reports, the most frequently used carbon materials in Li-ion cells and Li-S cells are 1D CNTs, 2D graphene and 3D nanostructured carbons, which can be carriers or dispersions as depicted in the Fig. 3(e and f). The porous carbons, even hierarchical hole structures, formed by intercalation also became hot spots. The carbon materials also include CNF, carbon nanorings (CNR), amorphous carbon and so on. Their coherent merits generally lie in lightweight feature, excellent toughness, rich mass transfer and conductivity, and stable mechanical property. The traditional fabrication is that carbon sources are deposited on LDH nanosheets through CVD method. But the large-scale manufacture is hindered because of expensive equipment and complex procedures. However, it is easy to form another domain in situ on LDHs or nanocarbon growing matrix. The design strategies of carbon composite structure can be divided into the formation of LDHs on carbon and the formation of carbon on LDHs. The deposition method of generating LDHs on carbon is adding materials with the function of adsorption for cations in the co-deposition solution. The electrostatic interaction promotes the precipitation of LDHs on the surface of the carbon substrate. Taking carbon cloth as a substrate, Yuan et al. [43] prepared a layered core-shell NiCo2S4@NiCo LDH nanoarray by three-step hydrothermal method. The precursor nanoarray, NiCo2S4 nanoarray and NiCo LDHs were synthesized in turn. Similar effective nanoscale substrates include CNFs, CNTs and graphene. Si et al. [44] obtained CNFs through electrospinning technology and carbonization. Then they prepared NiAl LDH nanosheets on CNTs in the nitrate solutions of Ni/Al. Through the strategy, delaminated GO nanosheets were simultaneously reduced to graphene during the co-precipitation process. Another structural design strategy is to form carbon on LDHs, which can be achieved through carbonization of the substance in intercalated galleries and situ growth. It mainly includes the following aspects: (1) Carbonization of the anion-intercalated LDHs: Owing to the delaminated structure and interlayer restriction of LDHs, various organic anions are inserted into the interlayers, which are translated into LDO/carbon nanocomposites after carbonization at moderate or high temperatures. The advantage of interlayer space expands the applications of LDHs as supported catalysts and multi-functional materials. In addition to anion exchange, the direct co-precipitation method is also the main strategy to realize intercalation. The transition metals in the cationic layer can induce the conversion of amorphous carbon during carbonization. Sun et al. [45] introduced metal ions which can be reduced in situ as metal catalysts, such as Co2+, Ni2+ and Fe2+, to promote graphitization of carbon. Besides carbon source, according to the requirements, sometimes the intercalated anions can also be regarded as the source of sulfur and phosphorus, etc. Yang et al. [46] adopted the nitrate solution and sodium dodecyl sulfonate (SDS) via conventional co-precipitation to obtain a high Co/Al ratio and DS−-intercalated LDHs. It is worth noting that the most intercalating reactions need to degas to avoid the intercalation of competitive carbonate anions. The DS−-intercalated LDHs were converted into conductive S-doped carbon coating as a dual source of molecules S and C. Liang et al. [47] intercalated dodecyl phosphate (SDP) to introduce P and C bi-molecules. The resulting ring-shaped core–shell C@Ni3P nanoparticles uniformly dispersed between conductive nanosheets. Lv et al. [48] synthesized NiCoAl LDHs on rGO supports via co-precipitation. After vulcanization and calcination within melamine, bimetallic nanoparticles encapsulated N-doped CNTs could be obtained. It was an integration that LDHs were produced on the carbonaceous carrier and new carbon materials were synthesized by intercalation. The reasonable co-doping like N, O, F, P, and S can improve conductivity and generate strong adsorption to trap lithium polysulfides. (2) In situ growth: In some cases, the LDHs only serve as catalytic templates without the function of energy storage. So they are subsequently removed. LDHs are endowed with the ability to derive thermally stable catalyst metal nanoparticles with controlled morphology and density. In this way, Zhao et al. [49] prepared the nanoparticles with bimodal size distribution to catalyze CNTs with different structures at the same time. Also, mesoporous carbon materials were designed by CVD using LDHs as hard templates. LDOs are also suitable carriers for the growth of nanocarbon. For instance, graphene and CNTs can be deposited on both sides of the sheet LDO templates [50]. There are differences in the deposition of carbon sources on the nanoparticles and LDO flakes at different temperatures, which can be utilized to synthesize carbon electrode materials with various structures. 2.3 Mechanisms of LDHs improving electrochemical performances As two different battery systems, Li-ion battery is optimized mainly by accelerating the migration of lithium ions and suppressing lithium dendrites. While physical confinement and chemical adsorption of lithium polysulfides and redox during the process of charge–discharge are primary mechanisms to improve the electrochemical performances of Li-S battery by applying some LDHs. 2.3.1 Accelerate the migration of lithium ions The ameliorated conductivity is one of the prominent features of LDH-based electrodes in Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries. The channels located between the layers and within the layers of LDHs can provide abundant diffusion pathways for lithium ions. Moreover, it has been shown that the greatly improved interface wettability of LDHs can provide tight contact and reduce interface resistance [51]. Thirdly, the multi-metal elements of LDHs are promising to make the resulting bi-active or multi-active synergistic substances show well-dispersed size at atomic level, which greatly affects the ability of electrode materials to conduct and storage lithium ions. Meanwhile, it is suitable for storing lithium ions and rapid charges transfer that the hollow polyhedron and other spatial morphologies self-assembled by LDH nanosheets. Lithium ions, charges and liquid electrolytes can easily access the nanoshells which dramatically shortens the diffusion path of lithium ions. And readily available carbon composition containing intercalation or carbon carrier allows fast electronic/ionic transportation. A recent study has shown that single-layer LDH nanosheets exhibited high in-plane conductivity of 10−1 S cm−1, which provided new ideas for LDHs to improve conductivity [52]. 2.3.2 Suppress lithium dendrites Taking the commercial PP separators as an example, weak polarization and poor interface compatibility lead to the uneven distribution of ionic flux and turbulence caused by the change of the local electric field. The LDH layer can adjust the obstacle [51]. According to the widely accepted diffusion model [53–55] as follow: (1) τ = π D · e C 0 μ a + μ Li + 2 / 2 J μ a which expounds the relationship between the effective electrode current density (J), anionic (μ a) and Li+ (μ Li + ) mobility, and the start time of growth for lithium dendrites (τ). It means that reducing the local current density is conducive to the long lifespan of cells before the growth of lithium dendrites. To be specific, it can effectively suppress dendrites through constructing an electrode or conductive scaffold with large specific surface area, nanoscale characteristic size, excellent conductivity (low resistance and weak polarization). Zhang et al. [56] applied the mechanism to develop an unstacked graphene conductive scaffolds as the matrix for lithium deposition. The way reduced local current density and suppressed the growth of lithium dendrites. And LDHs are appropriate to prepare porous scaffold as templates. The resulting ultra-low local current density was 4.0 × 10−5 mA cmg −2 at current density of 0.5 mA cmCu foil −2, ten-thousandth of that on ordinary Cu foil-based anode. Besides, the LDHs enhanced modulus will effectively resist the puncture of lithium dendrites to battery separators [51]. 2.3.3 Physical confinement and chemical adsorption The mechanism is mainly embodied in inhibiting the diffusion of lithium polysulfides through physical confinement and chemical adsorption in Li-S batteries. The physical confinements aim to minimize the escape of lithium polysulfides by physically absorbing them into porous hosts or establishing an external physical barrier. First of all, the unique hollow shape and other spatial morphologies self-assembled by LDH nanosheets can store high sulfur content, accommodate large volume expansion and physically prevent the outward diffusion of lithium polysulfides [57]. Secondly, as an important component of Li-S battery, separator or interlayer are modified by LDH nanosheets with the lateral direction of 2–3 μm. These overlapped nanosheets fill the slit pores on the separator as a physical shield [58]. And the lateral size of the nanosheets fits the characteristic length of electronic/ionic diffusion [59]. Besides, the micropore and mesopore of nanocarbon and the heterostructure with oxides or sulfides can be also acted as a physical barrier. However, in principle, physical confinement can only play a mitigating effect at the expense of sacrificing sulfur content. Attributing to abundant hydrophilic, sulfiphilic groups, hydroxyl radicals and exposed rich metal sites, LDHs exhibit excellent chemical adsorption and combination [7,60]. In addition, trivalent metal substitution brings a high density of positive charges, which endow LDHs with the charge characteristic as lithium polysulfides trappers. Meanwhile, conductivity and adsorbability are improved through some polar atoms introduced via LDHs (such as N−, O−, Cl−, Co−, B−, S−, Si−) and polar host materials (such as metal oxides, metal sulfides and metal fluorides) which capture lithium polysulfides well via “S covalent bond”. Li’s group [61] prepared nanoparticle-stacked metal nitride derived from NiCo LDHs as an interlayer (235 μm). It additionally serviced as an upper current collector which increased the additional space for the transfer of lithium polysulfides and adaptation of volume expansion of the sulfur electrode. Importantly, the hydrophilic metal −O group of oxide passivation layer bound with lithium polysulfides as a polar surface. The metal nitride alleviated the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides and given the cells outstanding cycle performance. 2.3.4 Catalyst redox Due to multi-electronic transferring, complex reactions and sluggish kinetics ensue in alkali metal–chalcogen batteries including Li-S battery [62]. Fortunately, LDHs are identified as an effective electro-catalyst for aprotic electrochemical reactions in Li-S cells. The fundamental way to solve the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides is to effectively promote the conversion of lithium polysulfides into solid Li2S2/Li2S during the discharge process. At the same time, the conversion of insoluble Li2S2/Li2S back to lithium polysulfides needs rapid reaction kinetics and activation energy in the charging process. Therefore, the introduction of compounds containing special functional groups can enhance the rate of redox reaction. LDH-derived metal nanoparticles, metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal nitride and metal phosphates, etc. are suitable as metal catalysts. The applied catalysts not only exhibit facilitated ions transfer, but also promote conversion kinetics through the sufficient “sulfiphilic” sites. For example, the oxides and Co nanoparticles in the cathode with CNTs on CoAl LDH nanosheets can effectively promote redox kinetics [63]. There exist strong interaction between Co nanoparticles and sulfur species, which can greatly improve the transformation kinetics between S8, Li2S x (4 < x < 8) and Li2S2/Li2S. However, the research on the catalytic evolution mechanism of LDHs has not yet appeared. The existing study revealed the evolution of the catalysts and the role of alkali metal cations and intermediates/reactants (such as lithium polysulfides) in the aprotic environment [62]. And the electrochemical phase evolution of electrocatalyst and active catalytic sites of LDHs can be identified, thus improving catalytic performance and assembling better batteries. 3 LDHs applied to lithium-ion battery 3.1 Anode materials The choices of anode materials determine the performances in terms of energy density, safety and reliability, etc. In previous studies, traditional anodes evolved include carbon, lithium titanate and silicon-based materials. The synthesis of electrode materials has been reported since 2006 for the applications of Li-ion batteries. The prepared LDHs have unique features of readily changing the metal cation and inserted anion, coupled with a wide range of M2+/M3+ ratio to serve as anode materials in Li-ion cells. Table S1 in supporting information displays the recent progress in the LDHs applied to anode materials for Li-ion cells. It is difficult to directly adopt LDHs as anode material for Li-ion cells. The natural mineral like MgAl LDHs without electrochemical activity and low electro-active CoAl LDHs, NiAl LDHs and CoNi LDHs must be converted into calcined products to exert values for energy storage. Hence, few relevant studies about it have been reported. The team of Shi [64] had advanced the work to prepare NiCo LDHs microspheres encapsulated with graphene nanosheets as the anode material. Meanwhile, the optimum mass ratio of LDHs/graphene was also investigated. The assembled cell reached reversible discharge capability of 1428, 1099, 671 and 328 mAh g−1 at 0.05, 0.2, 2 and 10 A g−1, respectively, as well as retention of 75% at 10 A g−1 after 10,000 cycles. The results were based on the prominent chemical reactivity of LDHs, and the rich conductivity and flexibility of graphene which buffer volume changes. Besides, the electrostatic interaction between LDHs and graphene caused them to be tightly anchored for facilitating charge transfer. Zhang et al. [65] also explored how to directly apply NiFe LDHs nanoflakes as the anode. The Ni2+ and Fe3+ were co-deposited on the surface of GO to form thin layered LDHs. Fig. 4 (g) exhibits the inner surface channel and the overall hierarchical pore structure. The storage behavior of lithium ions manifested in that the large number of electrons transferred from lithium ions to Ni2+ and Fe3+. Compared with the reported anode material, the adsorption energy of lithium ions in NiFe LDHs/rGO was extremely low, which reduced the energy of intercalation/deintercalation of lithium ions. Directly applying LDHs as anode materials for Li-ion batteries has certain advantages, but the above inevitable obstacles do exist. Therefore, strategy and design need to be further explored. At present, in the anodes, LDHs are generally acted as precursors or sacrifice templates to change the structure or realize composite. 3.1.1 Homogeneous dispersed multi-component Long before, the researchers explored multiple possibilities for LDHs as electrode materials. Li et al. [66] pioneered to introduce pure NiFe2O4 spinel derived from LDH precursors as anode materials of Li-ion batteries in 2006. During the calcination of NiFe LDHs, the oxidation of Fe2+ lost electrons to form pure magnetic MFe2O4. The assembled cell showed a high initial discharge capacity of 1239 mAh g−1 and a reversible capacity of 470 mAh g−1 after 20 cycles at C/8. The anode material with viable electrochemical properties needs to contain relatively well-constructed spinels, to cope with the plunge in capacity and low efficiency caused by SEI. With the help of the hierarchical structure of LDHs, Pan et al. [67] prepared the calcined product stacked CoMn2O4 nanoparticles with 50–100 nm, which were conducive to the transmission and de-lithiation. The prepared anodes with CoMn2O4 nanoparticles delivered a discharge capacity of 733 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 200 mA g−1. Combined with the merits of the small size of nanoparticles and other strategies, the cycling performance of Li-ion batteries from single metal oxide will be further improved. Except that oxides, Myoungho et al. [68] found that CoSn(OH)6 had superior electrochemical activity than that of the CoSn-based metal oxides. The assembled cell with the prepared rGO/CoSn(OH)6/amine-functionalized graphene composites, provided a high capacity of 1475 mAh g−1 over 100 cycles at 0.1 A g−1 and 650 mAh g−1 at 2.0 A g−1. The obtained results were attributed that GO/graphene stack immobilized the intermediate products, i.e. the CoSn nanoparticles and reversibly converted LiOH. It was more effective than Li2O (the product of discharge) in dispersing nanoparticles and buffering volume. Moreover, it helped to conversion/alloy reactions for the subsequent Li+ insertion/de-insertion as Fig. 4(a). However, the as-obtained products after calcination of LDHs are usually not single. The active substances contained bi-component or multi-component can provide additional capacity, and even the inert oxides can play the important role of buffering volume changes and preventing aggregation, such as the following ZnO, MgO and Al2O3 [69]. Woo et al. [70] reported the biactive ZnO/ZnFe2O4 nanocomposites by calcination of ZnFe LDH precursors in 2011, in which ZnO can act as a buffer domain for strain and agglomeration to improve the cycling capacity. Meanwhile, utilizing the property of dissolving of ZnO in aqueous media under high pH conditions, ZnFe2O4 porous nanoparticles were engineered by selectively etching to facilitate the mass transfer. Analogously, Min et al. [71] prepared nanoporous ZnO/ZnAl2O4 derived from ZnAl LDHs. And putting the sequence of carbon support behind, a carbon coating was introduced on the as-obtained metal oxide to improve conductivity. Liu et al. [72] prepared LDHs with adjustable size and morphology across the nanometer-micron scale directly on various alkali-resisted metal substrates, such as Zn and Cu. Taking ZnAl LDHs as an example, shown as Fig. 4(b), nanosheets were grown vertically on bivalent metal Zn coated substrate to finally obtain ZnO/ZnAl2O4 porous nanosheet film. The metal substrate acted as a dual role of reactants and supports, and LDHs greatly improved mechanical stability and adhesion. Importantly, as-prepared porous oxide film was directly integrated into the battery device with low cost and facile operation. It exhibited the first discharge capacity of 1275 mAh g−1 and 500 mAh g−1 over 10 cycles at 200 mA g−1. Wang et al. [73] obtained mesoporous spinel ferrite MgFe2O4/ZnFe2O4 composite by the thermal decomposition of MgZnFe LDHs, and retained slight-content inactive MgO via changing the etching crafts (Fig. 4(c)). Firstly, the alloying/conversion mechanism of ZnFe2O4 played a capacitor-like role, providing additional capacity in synergy with the active MgFe2O4 [74]. And the appropriate specific surface area, mesopore size distribution, and low interfacial resistance endowed Li-ion cells exceptional performance with a reversible capacity of 541 mAh g−1 under a high current of 2.0 A g−1 after 1000 cycles. As mentioned above, the multi-phases can form a firm connection in the interface via crystallographic similarity of different nanocrystals. Further speaking, the metal cations of LDHs are well-ordered arranged within the crystalline layer, which brings the well-dispersion of multi-components and the crystalline interfacial nanodomains. Uniform nanoscale dispersion provides more efficient active sites and makes lithium ions acquire the minimized diffusion length. Li et al. [75] synthesized highly dispersed bi-component CoO/CoFe2O4 nanocomposite from calcined CoFe LDHs with different molar ratios. In contrast with the physical mixture of the two phases, it possessed higher cycling stability with 735 mAh g−1 after 30 cycles at 100 mA g−1 when charge specific capacity was 844 mAh g−1. It was widely concerned that active materials of homogeneously dispersed multi-component were further extended to combine with carbon materials. Du’s team [76] not only prepared harmonious nanoscale dispersed CoO/CoFe2O4, but also encapsulated it in an intelligent integrated graphene framework by simple operation. The size of CoFe LDH precursors was adjusted to reduce the particle size of CoO/CoFe2O4, thereby expanding the contact interface between graphene and nanoparticles. Compared with the above uncoated two-phase oxides, G-CoO/CoFe2O4 composite displayed a reversible capacity of 600 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 80 cycles. Similarly, making graphene as the carbon scaffold, Wang et al. [77] synthesized Mn0.25Co0.75O solid solution dispersed at atomic scale which is exhibited in Fig. 4(d). The CoMn LDHs were chosen as a result of the comparable sizes of Mn2+/Co2+ and the immiscibility of MnO/CoO solid solution. The size of nanodomain strongly affected the ability to storage lithiums [78]. The prepared electrode delivered a reversible capacity of 1087 mAh g−1 after 1300 cycles at 2 A g−1. Wu et al. [79] obtained the well-dispersed CoO/Co3O4/N-C/Al2O3 composite materials from melamine/CoAl LDH mixtures in Fig. 4(e). The rich dispersibility was contributed to the lattice orientation and confinement of CoAl LDHs. The defects caused by N-doping on the carbon surface produced the low barrier penetration. So it endowed excellent electrochemical performances for electrodes due to the synergic effect of bi-active CoO/Co3O4, the buffering effect of Al2O3 and N-doped carbon as well as the high conductivity, such as the reversible capacity as high as 1078 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles at 100 mA g−1 (Fig. 4(f)). 3.1.2 Self-assembled architectures 3.1.2.1 Hollow polyhedron and Core-shell structure It is suitable for storing lithium ions and rapid charge transfer that the hollow polyhedron structures give the material larger interface area. Lithium ions, charges and liquid electrolytes can easily access the nanoshells which dramatically shortens the diffusion path and improves kinetics. What counts is that these structures can solve the capacity loss and poor stability suffered by volume changes of the electrode materials. The architectures are generally made from ZIFs with 3D structures such as dodecahedron, spindle-like or sphere, which are etched into hollow LDHs. Song et al. The core of Li-ion battery lies in the materials, especially the cathode materials which directly affect the performances of cells. For the practical application of large-scale systems, it is necessary to improve the rate capabilities of the cathodes with multiple metal oxide nanoparticles. And Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd. The method continuously washed residues, coated LDH layers of 5–20 nm on the surface, and formed new active materials by heat treatment. The LDH coating could be a combination of multiple metal ions, which prevented adverse reactions. It can be recycled to simplify the manufacturing process and reduced the cost, which means that LDHs applied for Li-ion cells are gradually becoming practical and commercialized. The developments of various electro-active compounds of LDHs with different components, novel architectures and plentiful carbon composites are respectively summarized above. The ideal consequents have been obtained in improving electronic transfer, accommodating volume expansion and maintaining cycling performances, etc. Besides, more recently, researchers have attempted to improve the electrolyte in Li-ion batteries with the help of special groups of LDHs.
