Firstly, the sizes of LDH nanosheets are analogic to the electronic/ionic diffusion length. The distance approximated the characteristic length of the physical interaction, which is suitable for collaborating with other components. Except for physical trapping, attributing to abundant hydrophilic, sulfiphilic groups, hydroxyl radicals and exposed rich metal sites, LDHs bring excellent chemical adsorption for lithium polysulfides. The delaminated structures enlarge the density of binding sites to heighten electro-catalysis and anchoring effects [128]. To maximize energy density and improve sulfur utilization, self-assembled nanosheets and carbon composite materials were conceived. It is noteworthy that LDHs exhibit the unique hierarchical structure and effectively accelerate the conversion of lithium polysulfides. The earliest researches on LDHs applied in Li-S batteries are that the prepared LDHs catalyzed carbon growth by Zhang et al. in the early 2010s [107,129]. Tables S3–S5 illustrate intuitively that many LDHs involved in Li-S cells as separators or interlayers, sulfur hosts, and catalyst precursors, respectively. Meanwhile, they all show the corresponding loading content of sulfur, initial reversible capacity and cycling performances. 4.1 Separators and interlayers One of the important parameters in evaluating the performance of the separators is whether the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides could be effectively suppressed. The lithium polysulfides, which freely migrate and react with the lithium, are a major detriment for the active materials and Columbic efficiency. Undoubtedly, it is appropriate to intercept lithium polysulfides born negative charges through the materials with cationic charges. It had been demonstrated by previous experiments that organic polymers with cationic charges, such as polyethylene glycol, gelatin and polyvinyl amine, could be used as chemical shields. But cationic inorganic materials were rarely researched. For example, LDHs materials modified the separators of Li-S batteries. Their two-dimensional, lightweight and heat-resistance features ensure stabilized and tight contact between the separator and the cathode. Peng et al. [59] made the binary cooperative complementary interface by decorating NiFe LDH nanoplates on the mesoporous N-doped graphene substrate (NG). The method established “amphiphilic” heterogeneous surfaces via “lithiophilic” N, O-doped graphene and “sulfiphilic” LDHs. The existing form of the nanoplate with lateral size of less than 5 nm fitted the characteristic length of electrons/ions diffusion. The LDHs not only chemically adsorbed lithium polysulfides via forming M−O(H) bonds, but also possessed layered structure which enlarged the density of binding sites as shown in Fig. 9 (a). The LDH and NG synergistically enhanced M−S interaction through strain within LDH lattice. It realized the good catalytic function for redox and effective restriction for lithium polysulfides. The Li-S batteries with the as-described separator exhibited a high initial capacity of 1192 mAh g−1 at C/20 and 709 mAh g−1 at 2.0C. And the low capacity decay rate of only 0.06% per cycle after 1000charge/discharge cycles was obtained. Zhou et al. [58] modified the commercial Celgard polypropylene (PP) separator by coating MgAl LDH sheets. Because of the high dispersion of LDH flakes, it could be realized simply by the vacuum filtration. The superiority of Mg2Al LDHs is that the highest positive charge density of M2+/M3+ (4.1/nm2) strengthens the electrostatic absorption for lithium polysulfides. What’s more, Mg and Al are electrochemically inert metal without secondary action to disturb capacity. The capacity decay rate reduced from 0.29%/cycle of the ordinary separator to 0.18%. Importantly, the high charge density and physical/chemical trapping strategies minimized the loading of the modified layer (a density of 0.018 mg cm−2 and thickness of 20–30 nm) without sacrificing energy density and conductivity. Similarly, Cui et al. [130] recently constructed bi-functional barriers, in which MgAl LDH nanosheets and GO nanosheets were alternatively LBL self-assembled on commercial PP separator based on electrostatic interaction as illustrated in Fig. 9(b). As a barrier, a set of bilayer films with a thickness of about 1.1 nm prevented the migration of most lithium polysulfides (>1.5 nm). As a rectifier for lithium ions, motion-restricted channels ensured lithium ions passed through uniformly, which subsequently equalized the local density of ions in anode and inhibited lithium dendrites. The high initial discharge capacity of cells assembled with separators was 1092 mAh g−1 and capacity decay was 0.08% per cycle more than 500cycles at 0.2C. In addition, some scholars introduced LDHs into the interlayers between cathode and separator to establish a reliable barrier for capturing and reusing lithium polysulfides. Zhang et al. [34] constructed CNFs vertically rooted on a hierarchical lightweight carbon fabric framework (Fig. 9(d)). The NiCo LDHs hollow polyhedrons were obtained from ZIFs-67 and embedded on the carbon fabric surface uniformly, where the formed metal nanoparticles catalyzed the growth of CNFs in turn. The CNFs were like multi-functional tentacles, which ensured conductivity at various distances and exposed adsorptive and catalytic sites. The metal particles and M−N−C coordination played a significant role in adsorbing and converting lithium polysulfides and elemental sulfur [131]. The cells provided a long lifespan of 1000 cycles with a capacity decay rate of 0.018% and a high capacity of 625.9 mAh g−1 at 3C (Fig. 9(e and f)). Also based on the carbon textile framework, Liu et al. [132] proposed an effective interlayer. The NiCo LDHs nucleated and grew on carbon textile and were vulcanized to obtain the interconnected NiCo2S4 nanosheets array (Fig. 9(c)). The strong binding energy of NiCo2S4 and hierarchical structure with large specific surface area and rich mesopores were more efficient in adsorbing lithium polysulfides as demonstrated in Fig. 9(g). Compared with batteries without an interlayer, the discharge capacity and the sulfur utilization rate were increased by 116% and 52.4% at 0.1C respectively. Ultra-stable cycling performance with decay rate as low as 0.018%/cycle over 500 cycles at 0.5C was obtained. They also designed NiCo2S4 nanosheets grown in-situ on PP separators in Fig. 9(h) [133]. The low-temperature reaction (90 °C), mechanical compression and no adhesive ensured that the film was lightweight (0.148 mg cm−2) and ultra-thin (0.8 μm). So it had little impact on sulfur content and volumetric energy density. Primordially functional groups on PP separator immobilized LDH crystal seeds, which allowed the separator had superior density and stability to block the diffusion of lithium polysulfides. And unlike traditional coating or vacuum filtration technology, the method did not require additional adhesives, thus allowing the particles to be perfectly connected and aligned. It could endow cell extremely low capacity decay of 0.056%/cycle over 500 cycles at 0.5C. 4.2 Sulfur hosts Considering most sulfur species are in battery cathode, the restriction depending solely on the separators or interlayers might be limited, which only touch a relatively small part of lithium polysulfides. In recent years, inorganic anchored materials, such as metal oxides [134,135] and metal hydroxides [136,137], have attracted widespread attention as sulfur host materials [138]. LDHs have advanced advantages as sulfur hosts in Li-S cells. First of all, the spatial morphologies self-assembled by LDH nanosheets and carbon cathodes catalyzed by LDHs play a role in physical confining lithium polysulfides. Secondly, LDHs and derivatives carry with abundant hydrophilic groups, hydroxyl groups and metal sites to chemically bind lithium polysulfides. And the previous studies have demonstrated that the electro-catalysis of derivatives from LDHs could accelerate the redox reactions to control dissolution and conversion of lithium polysulfides [139]. In this regard, researchers have done plenty of practices to reduce the loss of sulfur and stabilize performances. The following are the main functions of LDHs as the sulfur host in Li-S battery. 4.2.1 Physical confinement The first thing worth paying attention to is the hollow shape and other spatial morphologies self-assembled by LDH nanosheets, in which shell structures well prevent the outward diffusion of lithium polysulfides. At the same time, the internal spaces realize high sulfur loading and accommodate volumetric expansion. Except for special architectures, the overlapped nanosheets, oxides, sulfides or nanocarbons on the electrode materials also fill the slit pores as physical barriers. Zhang and coworkers [140] prepared the hollow NiFe LDH spindle-like polyhedrons and made sulfur impregnate into them by melting-diffusion method (Fig. 10 (a)). The shell structure well limited the diffusion of lithium polysulfides, met the requirement of high sulfur loading and accommodated the huge volumetric expansion. Besides, the LDH shells could be regarded as chemical bonding region of sulfiphilic sites. So a high discharge capacity of 1091 mAh g−1 at 0.2C and a low fading rate of 0.04% per cycle over 1000cycles at 1.0C can be achieved. They also reported double-shelled nanocages consisted of inner Co(OH)2 and outer NiCo LDHs from rhombic dodecahedral ZIF-67 [136]. The appreciable yolk-shell structure possessed the smooth inner layer and outer layer composed of interconnected tiny nanosheets in Fig. 10(b). It continued the previous research adopting Co(OH)2 as effective sulfur host and introduced LDH shell to construct higher areal mass loading (up to 75 wt% of sulfur content) and larger functional surface [141]. The obtained composite maintained a reversible capacity of 653 mAh g−1 after the 100th cycle. The micropore and mesopore in the cathode can also effectively prevent the migration of lithium polysulfides. Therefore, nanocarbon materials are considered as the excellent physical barriers, which possess porous structure, adequate active sites and rapid reaction kinetics. The porous carbon-based materials mainly include porous CNTs, porous graphene, CNFs, carbon paper and hybrid carbon (multiple carbon composites and micro/mesoporous carbon composites) [142]. Chen et al. [138] firstly reported the composite materials by combining LDHs and biomass-derived carbon (BC) to promote pristine porous carbons as sulfur hosts as shown in Fig. 10(c). The advantages of BC lied in large specific surface area, adjustable hierarchical pores and functional interface. The in-situ growth of LDHs on the surface of BC formed a narrow space to strengthen electro-catalysis and anchoring effects. A cooperative interface effectively encapsulated lithium polysulfides and compensated the cycling property for BC. A high initial discharge capacity with 1216.3 mAh g−1 at 0.2C was obtained for the batteries with the as-prepared cathode. As we all know, CNTs are tend to agglomerate and graphene may be stacked between layers due to strong van der Waals forces. On account of the disadvantages, researches directly synthesized carbon-based materials on various matrices, which could realize controlled hybridization and uniform dispersion [129,143,144]. So, the structural adjusting of the catalytic template is the key to successfully prepare carbon materials. Surprisingly, LDHs play an excellent role as templates to catalyze the growth of nanocarbon materials through hierarchical structure and strong interaction of metal nanoparticles-support. Zhang et al. [145] pioneered the use of pure single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) for the nanocomposite electrode of the Li-S cells. The composite cathodes with SWCNT@S coaxial nanocables were fabricated on FeMgAl LDH flakes by melting diffusion. They also introduced polyethylene glycol (PEG) barrier layer to modify the surface, which utilized the ether groups to capture lithium polysulfides. So, the modified SWCNT@S cathode exhibited high reversible capacities of 1005 and 639 mAh g−1 for the initial charge at 0.5C and over 100cycles at 1.0C, respectively. It is worth mentioning that they also adopted FeMoMgAl LDHs as the catalytic templates to self-assembly hierarchical vine-tree-like CNTs [49]. The combination of SWCNTs and MWCNTs was similar to the flexible vines and rigid trees presented in Fig. 10(f−h). However, the in-situ growth required that the nanoparticles had the bimodal size distribution to promote the growth of two types of CNTs, respectively. The LDO could provide two types of catalytic templates. Additionally, LDHs affected the size and density of nanoparticles to determine the number and diameter of CNTs. Zhao and coworkers also synthesized other types of CNTs using LDHs as catalytic precursors. For instance, a hierarchical SWCNTs/DWCNTs composite interlinked to the flakes was fabricated by LDHs with multiple combinations of metal cations [129]. The CNT-array double helices were formed on the surface of the FeMoMgAl LDH films [146]. It utilized the rotation stress-induced self-organizing mechanism and space confinement. It is also possible to alter the metal cations of LDH flakes to create the single-walled, double-walled and multi-walled CNT-array double helices. And the perpendicular FeMoMgAl LDH films were used to fabricate well-oriented and metal-enriched short aligned SWCNTs of less than 1 μm [147]. Besides, they synthesized metal nanoparticle catalysts with excellent properties through FeMgAl LDHs. The nanoparticles were optimized by guest–host mediated LDH which destroyed the original anions and re-introduced MoO4 2− [107]. Furthermore, 3D graphene/SWCNT hybrids combining 1D SWCNTs and 2D graphene possessed many excellent features, such as mechanical property, thermal property and good energy storage. But the synthesis of SWCNTs required extremely strict conditions. So Zhao et al. [50] designed tiny and thermally stable nanoparticles catalyst and uniform substrate to fabricate graphene/SWCNT hybrids as displayed in Fig. 10(d and e). The graphene/SWCNT hybrids were catalyzed on FeMgAl LDO flakes at high-temperature over 950 °C. As a hard template for the deposition of graphene, the special layered architecture of LDHs facilitated to produce embedded high-density metal nanoparticles. The cell exhibited high initial reversible capacity as large as 928 mAh g−1 at 1 C with sulfur contents of 60%. And a high rate capacity of 650 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 5C was achieved. Peng et al. [148] prepared the interconnected sp2-hybridized graphene/SWCNT network as scaffold to cooperate with activated pyrolytic carbon. The analogous method was adopted to catalyze the CVD growth on FeMoMgAl LDHs. The hierarchical all-carbon architectures not only retained complete electronic pathways, but also had rich interconnected meso-/micropores which could accommodate sulfur and lithium polysulfides. Besides, owing to the strong confinement of micro-/mesopores, S8 crystal was transformed into amorphous cyclo-S8 molecular cluster, thus suppressing the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides. Therefore, the composite cathode with a high rate capability of 809 mAh g−1 at 10C maintained a reversible capacity of 887 mAh g−1 after 150 cycles at 1 C. However, porous cathode materials require content of host material up to 30 wt%−60 wt%. Sulfur loading has to be reduced which sacrifices most of the energy density. Cheng et al. [149] were committed to solving this problem. They explored aligned CNTs/sulfur composite cathode to achieve the high sulfur loading. The short aligned CNTs acted as interconnect conductive scaffold, which were catalyzed to grow directionally on the derivatives of FeMgAl LDHs. The uniqueness lied in the tunable structure with straight holes, neat arrangement, low density of the CNTs and no conductive agents were required. These advantages facilitated the well-distribution of sulfur particles, optimized channels for transmission and reduced capacity occupancy. Especially, the ordered accumulation of single CNTs provided a lower conductive percolation threshold of 0.0025 wt% compared with 0.1 wt%–4.0 wt% of agglomerated CNTs. It meant that the high volumetric energy density could be achieved with low nanocarbon loading. The cathode with high sulfur loading of 90 wt% and tap density of 1.98 g cm−3 could increase energy density significantly. 4.2.2 Chemical adsorption Attributing to abundant hydrophilic, sulfiphilic groups, hydroxyl radicals and exposed rich metal sites, LDHs exhibit excellent chemical adsorption to lithium polysulfides [7,60]. In addition, the substitution of trivalent metal brings a high density of positive charges, which endow LDHs and their derivatives with the negatively charge characteristic to become lithium polysulfides trappers. A composite cathode designed by sulfur and MgAl LDH-CNTs was proposed by Hwang et al. [137], which load high sulfur contents (55%) corresponded to 4.0 mg cm−2 in the freestanding electrode. The porous network quickly conducted ionic transport and provided more active sites. It represented superb absorptive ability for lithium polysulfides owing to the hydroxyl groups on LDHs and CNTs, which enhanced redox reactions. As a result, the assembled battery with the cathode and PP separator exhibited the high initial capacity of 1200 mAh g−1 at 0.1C. Additionally, the cathode combining with a graphene-PP-Al2O3 separator [137] delivered a high discharge capacity of 1375 mAh g−1 at 0.1C. It is helpful to introduce some polar atoms (such as N−, O−, Cl−, Co−, B−, S− and Si−) and other atoms to improve conductivity and provide strong adsorption for lithium polysulfides. Through the studies of theoretical calculation and DFT, these heteroatoms exhibited strong chemical bonds for lithium polysulfides. They can adsorb lithium polysulfides through the mechanisms of the dissociative role, the destructive principle and the intact adsorptions function [150]. In particular, appropriate chemical dopings of N atoms, O atoms and co-doping are more conducive to anchor and absorb lithium polysulfides [151]. The team of Chen focused on the synergistic role of Co and N co-doped carbon materials in preserving and accelerating the conversion of soluble lithium polysulfides [152,153]. The metal anions were intercalated CoAl LDHs to induce the self-assembly for hollow carbonaceous microflowers (Fig. 11 (a)). The prepared structure with the high sulfur loading of 82% was composed of multiple curved nanosheets oriented and connected at different angles. The LDHs were transformed into dew-like nanoparticles evenly distributed on the petals. The obtained electrode exhibited a great rate capacity of 611 mAh g−1 at 2C and a decay rate of 0.069%/cycle at 0.5C. And Chen et al. [154] reported ordered hollow nanocages with Co9S8 domains uniformly and intimately embedded on NiCo LDHs. Instead of carbon substrate, the conductive network constituted by Co9S8 achieved efficient transfer for electrons and lithium ions, which were fixed by the shell to avoid aggregation as Fig. 11(c). Apart from the physical trapping for lithium polysulfides by heterogeneous structures described above, O-containing groups and Co-S sites also facilitated the adsorption and transformation. The cathode material delivered high sulfur load of 79%, excellent discharge capacity of 1339.1 mAh g−1 at 0.01C, especially rare ultra-long cycle stability with capacity decay of 0.047% over 1500 cycles at 1C (Fig. 11(d)). The heteroatoms on the carbon materials possess effective chemical adsorption and convenient charge transfer. But, in general, these heteroatom-doped carbon materials or conductive polymers can only provide weak chemical bonding via “Li bonds”. While many polar host materials (such as metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal fluorides) can form strong chemical bonds to well capture lithium polysulfides through “S covalent bonds”. The metal oxides, for example, not only bind to lithium ions in lithium polysulfides through O atom, but also utilize chemical bonds from metal ions to provide smooth surface diffusion, allowing the sulfide to be deposited efficiently on the electrodes. The double-shelled Co3O4/CNTs as sulfur hosts were designed by Zhou’s group [155]. Polydopamine was coated on LDHs with hollow nanocage structure to form double-shell nanocages as Fig. 11(e). The excellent conductivity of the outer carbon shells accelerated electronic transfer. And the polar Co3O4 could trap lithium polysulfides in the nanocages through the above mechanisms. The sulfur content of the Co3O4/C nanocage with the surface area of 306.11 m2 g−1 was up to 70 wt%. The cathode reached an initial capacity of 1076 mAh g−1 and 889 mAh g−1 at 0.2C and 1C, respectively. And low capacity decay of 0.083% after 500 cycles at 1C was achieved. The double-shell structures have the potential to be commercialized in improving sulfur content and buffering volume changes. 4.2.3 Improving reaction kinetics Given the requirements of the high sulfur loading and long cycling, the effects of limiting lithium polysulfides through the two mechanisms are limited. The restriction or adsorption is passive which makes it difficult for lithium polysulfides to be reused. The fundamental way to solve the “shuttle effect” is to effectively promote the conversion of lithium polysulfides into solid Li2S2/Li2S during the discharging process. At the same time, the conversion of insoluble Li2S2/Li2S back to lithium polysulfides needs rapid reaction kinetics and activation energy in the charging process. Therefore, the introduction of compounds containing special functional groups can enhance the rate of redox reaction. The LDH-derived metal nanoparticles, metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal nitride and metal phosphates, etc. are suitable to be acted as catalysts. Li et al. [156] combined the metal oxides and functional carbon materials, and attached the CNTs to the NiCo LDO nanocages as Fig. 11(b). As CNTs were added, the size of NiCo LDOs decreased due to the inhibition of grain growth. The increased active sites and specific surface areas showed better adsorptive and catalytic properties. Meanwhile, the strategy settled the problems of the cathode materials with mixed transition metal oxides: inevitable volume changes and poor structural stability. The cell exhibited outstanding discharge capacities of 1421.7, 1030.6 and 611.9 mAh g−1 at 0.1C, 0.5C, and 1C, respectively. Besides the noble metal (such as Pt), transition metals exhibit excellent catalytic activities for electrochemical reactions. For example, there exist strong interactions between Co nanoparticles and sulfur species, which facilitate to capture and mutual transform of lithium polysulfides. More importantly, Co nanoparticles can greatly improve the kinetics for the transformation among S8, Li2S x (4 < x < 8) and Li2S2/Li2S. Qiu et al. [63] prepared sulfur hosts formed by the Co-embedded and N-doped CNTs on both sides of the CoAl LDH nanosheets. The Co2+ was converted to metal Co nanoparticle which served as the adsorptive and catalytic site to facilitate redox kinetics for lithium polysulfides. Meantime, Al atom inhibited the local aggregation of Co and promoted Co nanoparticles to generate uniformly. The CNTs growing vertically on the CoAl LDHs surface could avoid the stacking of nanosheets which increased many pores containing sulfur. The as-battery exhibited high sulfur utilization of 93%, excellent discharge capability of 1552 mAh g−1 at 0.1C, good rate capability of 860 mAh g−1 at 2C and low capacity decay rate of 0.04%/cycle. And Li et al. formerly synthesized a 3D porous Co and N-doped graphitic carbon composite only applying precursor ZIF-67 [153]. Now they have further elevated the method [157]. A sandwich-like compound catalyst was produced by regulating ZIF-67 to nucleate and grow on both surfaces of the CoAl LDH flakes. Fig. 11(f and g) presents the synthetic process of the cellular composite. The sulfur composite cathode with quasi-2D cellular and honeycomb architecture was rich in Co − N dual catalytic sites. The special structure required fewer materials, but possessed micro-/mesopores and larger specific surface area (459.03 m2 g−1), thereby achieving high sulfur loading (7.5 mg cm−2) and sulfur content (93.6 wt%). It also contributed to control the volumic changes and diffuse lithium ions. The as-prepared cell obtained a high initial specific capacity of 1674 mAh g−1 at 0.05C and a slow capacity loss rate of 0.02% per cycle after 850 cycles at 2C. Recently, Shao et al. [158] doped S of mechanical alloying into the graphene lattice via ball milling method, which provided a new idea for carbon-based sulfur host catalyzed by LDHs. Expect for meeting physical confinements and providing abundant active sites, the heterojunction of sulfur nanocrystals band and the 3D network of S-doped carbon can realize effective ionic and electronic transport and promote redox reactions. In summary, the reported LDH-based separators are generally commercial separators modified by applying LDHs to improve the interception and adsorption for lithium polysulfides. And for pursuing lightweight, the LDH nanosheets applied to separators need to be tiled and uniform on the traditional separators by mechanical shaking [106]. In terms of structure, they need to meet the requirements of high porosity, small pore size, large specific surface area, excellent mechanical properties and superior liquid retain-ability. It must provide smooth channel for lithium ionic transmission and possess good compatibility with the surface of the electrode. While as the sulfur hosts in the cathodes, LDHs need to meet a certain amount of sulfur loading and provide confinement and conversion of lithium polysulfides. Most of the previous studies have focused on LDHs self-assembled into hollow structures and catalyzed nanocarbon. However, LDH as an inactive material, the additional weight itself directly affects the actual energy density of the battery. The decrease in energy density caused by excessive addition may far exceed the performance gain it brings. So, it is also worthy of further exploration to achieve a balance between the content and structure of LDHs and their corresponding electrochemical performances of batteries. 5 Conclusions and perspective In this review, we systematically review the recent progress in LDHs for Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries concerning separator, interlayer, cathodes and anodes (Fig. 12 ). Meanwhile, the existing synthetic approaches of conventional LDH nanosheets and specially designed preparation including hollow polyhedra, core–shell structures, layer-by-layer and carbon composites were elaborated. The advanced structural and combinatorial designs of LDHs and their derivatives are the key factors to construct two kinds of batteries with outstanding electrochemical performances. The basic forms of applying LDHs to the batteries are transforming into active substances such as metal oxides, sulfides, nitrides and phosphates. The bi-component or multi-component can provide additional capacity and improve cycling lifespan compared to the single metallic compound. Moreover, calcined product metal nanoparticles are also common in Li-ion cells. Currently, the developments of LDHs-based materials for cells mainly focus on the design of multiple architectures and the combination with nanocarbon. Structurally, hollow polyhedrons, multi-shelled nanocages and core–shell architectures depend on the templates. Layer-by-layer structure, nanowall arrays and other elaborate designs like flower-shape and sandwich-type base on the laminar morphology and self-assembly. The abnormal structures increase specific surface area, exposure active sites, accommodate volume expansion and maximize the contact between electrolytes and electrodes. As for combining with nanocarbon, there are two main mechanisms according to whether LDHs participate in the operation of batteries. One is that LDHs only catalyze the growth of nanocarbon as templates. They can catalyze different types of nanocarbon simultaneously by different compositions and sizes of nanoparticles under the simple operation. LDHs play a practical role in another mechanism, which are converted into active substances for energy storage and adsorption. Especially, the unparalleled intercalated feature of LDHs is easy to achieve multi-metal embedding and heteroatom doping. The heteroatoms can act as electron donors in the carbon lattice and facilitate the transformation of lithium polysulfides. The introduced metals synergistically prevent other metals from the local aggregation. And in Li-S cells, as separators and electrode materials, LDHs can effectively inhibit “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides and greatly promote redox due to increasing the adsorptive capacity and binding site. LDHs have evolved as significant elements for preparing various components of cells. However, some challenges should be solved for subsequent development of LDHs in Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries. (1) Preparation of LDHs: Among the reported synthetic strategies of LDHs for Li-based batteries, the most universal is the co-precipitation method. Some facts are discovered that the performances for storing energy of hydrothermal products are relatively excellent. But the conditions with high temperature and pressure are strict and the utilization rate of reactants is slightly lower. Besides, the LDHs prepared by the electro-deposition also exhibit a higher specific capacitance. However, their disadvantages lie in that it is difficult to separate the precipitated double hydroxide layers with the matrix as the external electrodes, which limit the large-scale application. While it is currently considered that the co-precipitation with simple operation and large yield has the potential for industrial production. However, there exists the drawback of uneven micro-mixing in the reaction process, slightly larger size, poor uniformity and aggregation of nanoflakes. (2) LDH/nanocarbon composite materials: Firstly, as for the growth of one component on another one, the size and scale of the products are restricted due to the nanoscale size of the matrix. Secondly, taking nanocarbon with large length as an example, such as CNTs, CNFs and nanowires, dense hydroxide layer is formed initially at the bottom of nanocarbon arrays when they grow on LDH platelets to enhance adhesion. It is no doubt that such a dense layer actually becomes “dead volume”, restricting the access of electrolyte during the electrochemical reaction process. On the contrary, when nanosheets grow directly on the surface of the CNFs, they can be stabilized as the wall-like architecture. However, these interconnected walls refuse lithium ions in the electrolyte to diffuse along the surface of carbon materials, resulting in poor rate performance. Furthermore, the reduction of the contact between the substrate and the LDH nanowall arrays may result in the shedding of the active substance. Sometimes, the core–shell structures can be introduced to accommodate volume expansion and address the problem that the electrolyte is difficult to contact the electrode. But such post-treatments are more complex and have little significance for the structural defects such as “dead volume” and weak contact. Finally, there are still inadequate understandings of the mechanism for assembly and the relationship among the synthetic route, structure and property of LDH/nanocarbon composite. (3) The conductivity of LDHs: The poor conductivity causes the electronic transfer to be hindered during the redox process, which is the bottleneck of the most batteries. In addition to carbon composite materials, single LDHs can also be doped with metals or combined with conductive polymers. These ways will become inevitable trends in researches of LDHs. (4) Large-scale applications: For the two classes of cells, at present, it is still difficult to achieve mass and commercialized production due to high cost and technical complications. Considering the existing defects of Li-ion cells and Li-S cells with LDHs, we look forward to further developments and make reasonable and achievable plans. (1) In terms of LDHs themselves, the raw materials with low cost, environmentally friendly and superior conductivity should be emphatically researched. And the sizes of LDHs are accurately controlled toward smaller and more uniform as required. Moreover, owing to the limited molar ratio of binary LDHs, the relatively more inactive products are produced after calcination, which greatly reduces specific capacity. Therefore, it inspires us to explore ternary LDHs to optimize the combination of elements. And the ternary LDHs may produce unexpected effects based on metal ions and higher electroactivity, especially the ternary cathode materials applied in Li-ion batteries. The efficient LDH-based electro-components are further developed through multi-active synergistic components, multi-metal embedding and heteroatom doping. (2) Given that various LDHs exhibit different electrochemical properties, it inspires us to select the optimal combination of metals and interlayer anions. So far, the more frequently mentioned combinations of metal ions in the two batteries include NiAl, NiCo, NiFe, CoAl, MgAl and so on. The properties of single metal elements and combinations need to be considered comprehensively. Nickel-based LDHs, for instance, exhibit eco-friendly feature, exceptional conductivity and low cost which make it a priority in many cases [159]. The form of hierarchical nanostructures and conductive coatings brings attention to Mn [160]. Meanwhile, distinct properties of cations also require personalized solutions. The relatively low mass transfer of NiAl LDHs can be overcome by adding conductive materials. And the major roadblock of Co-based LDHs is lacking cycling stability [161]. There are still numerous high-performance metals that have not been reported, such as the Ti-based LDH which maintains intrinsically structural stability when the electrons are inserted and extracted [162]. (3) On the structure, advanced designs of LDH nanosheets and novel LDH-based composite materials should be created and strengthened, such as the multi-layer structure attached to the template large enough, nanosheets superimposed spherical structure and catalytic nanoparticles of multiple types. (4) It is an important task to explore the higher conductivity of LDH-based electrochemical materials. Some carbon materials with especial structures are preferred as upper current collectors to reduce the charge transfer resistance. However, the relationship between the porous carbon structure and electronic transfer needs to be further studied. Some inorganic materials also possess excellent conductivity, such as MXene, nickel foam and black phosphorus nanosheets. Meanwhile, much attention should be paid to the functional coordination in the battery. In Li-S cells, the materials with high conductivity and strong adsorbability should be combined to complement each other. And it is necessary to explore the stacking modes of laminates, the relationship between the conductivity of LDH itself and the types of metal and guest anions, and the structures of subject and guest. Further efforts are required to upgrade the manufacturing technologies and optimize systems of composite materials including LDHs/carbon and LDHs/polymer, to promote energy density and rate performance of battery though ordered nanostructures. (5) In Li-S batteries, metal lithium anode faces more problems than the cathode. But there are rare reports about LDHs to improve the anode so far. Zhang et al. [163] proposed that large areas of sulfur cathode led to high concentration of lithium polysulfides and corrosion of lithium metal anode. And inappropriate conductive interlayer easily prevented lithium polysulfides intermediates from spreading to anode [164]. Therefore, we may provide appropriate solutions and speculate on the feasibility to utilize LDHs to minimize the corrosion of the anode and reduce impedance: Firstly, high-performance sulfur host, separator and interlayer should be designed through LDHs to affect indirectly the anode. Secondly, LDHs could be applied to make an ex-situ conformal coating on the anode to isolate lithium from electrolytes. (6) In the future, the databases of LDHs should be established, which will involve the relationships among the elements of LDHs. The contents should include anions, cations, raw materials, synthetic strategies, morphologies, application means, composite modes, the final performances of the resulting batteries and so on. By establishing the model or formula, we can get intuitively the feasible degree of matching various elements and optimizing the combination. Although certain challenges still exist, LDHs have also been proved to be capable of taking part in different components of Li-ion cells and Li-S cells increasingly and bringing results beyond imagination. With the advances in new technologies and fields, it will emerge a variety of means which are more efficient, more convenient and exhibit higher utilization rate. The review is expected to stimulate more profound work to promote LDHs toward electrochemical fields and accelerate the feasibility of Li-ion cells and Li-S cells for energy-storage applications. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery and lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery have attracted significant attention as promising components for large-scale energy storage because of high theoretical capacity of Li, excellent energy density or environmental friendness for two kinds of batteries. However, there still exist some respective obstacles for commercial applications, such as limited theoretical capacity, high cost and low conductivity of Li-ion cells or shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides of Li-S cells. As typical two-dimensional materials, layered double hydroxides (LDHs) exhibit excellent potential in the field of energy storage due to facile tunability of composition, structure and morphology as well as convenient composite and strong catalytic properties. Consequently, various LDHs toward novel separators or interlayers, cathodes, anodes, and interesting catalytic templates are researched to resolve these challenges. In this review, the recent progress for LDHs applied in Li-ion batteries and Li-S batteries including the synthesis methods, designs and applications is presented and reviewed. Meanwhile, the existing challenges and future perspectives associated with material designs and practical applications of LDHs for these two classes of cells are discussed. WeWe hope that the review can attract more attention and inspire more profound researches toward the LDH-based electrochemical materials for energy storage.
